I'm not a Trump fan but why are people so against the wall? A country has a right to sovereignty. And $14B isn't much and will create jobs.
5/ Not to mention you cannot attract tech cos when you have a rep of being hostile to disruption (aka Uber)
4/ solutions must attract/retain good people to city, and nurture cross-polination of knowledge/talent. Grants and tax breaks are not enough
3/ Politicians/bureaucrats think in linear input-output. Startups don’t have that luxury - must think of non-linear / dynamic systems.
2/ Startups + tech companies are attracted to cities with existing tech talent, infrastructure. Creating one from scratch is tough af
Building a local tech ecosystem is itself a chicken+egg network-effect problem. Aka a startup. Which is why politicians are so bad at it.

@mtnbvan their mandate has been flawed. Audits should not be based on ROI or ease. Social costs are greater than financial nickel and diming

gov's role should not just be collecting $ but promoting confidence in system/shared responsibility by punishing shirking even at a loss
Which is why tax cheats/loopholes cost more to system than revenue loss. They create permanent fissures and resentments.
What politicians don't understand is that people's appetite for taxes is proportional to perceived fairness of tax burden
